column6: "a quick question" (#[http://groups.yahoo.com/group/mythsoc/message/24071 24071] and related messages; dated 29 January 2013)
column7: [http://groups.yahoo.com/group/mythsoc/ Mytsoc mailing list] (accessed 30 January 2012)</ref> was one of the languages spoken by the [[Elves]]. It was the tongue that developed among those non-[[Teleri|Telerin]] [[Elves]] who reached [[Aman]] (the [[Calaquendi|High Elves]]) from an earlier language called [[Common Eldarin]]. Quenya was typically written with the [[Tengwar]] of [[Fëanor]]. An older script

column1: Of the three clans of Elves in Aman
column2: the [[Noldor]] and the [[Vanyar]] spoke slightly different
column4: dialects of Quenya (''Noldorin Quenya'' and ''[[Vanyarin|Vanyarin Quenya]]'' respectively). The word Quenya
column7: since it was the only Quenya dialect spoken in [[Middle-earth]].

column1: The language was also adopted by the [[Valar]] who also made some new introductions into it from their [[Valarin|own language]]
column2: though these loanwords are more numerous in the Vanyarin dialect than the Noldorin one. This is probably the case because of the enduringly close relationship the Vanyar had with the Valar. The third clan in Aman
column6: although this was by some seen as a dialect of Quenya which was untrue in a historic perspective but plausible in a linguistic one; the languages did not share a common history but were very much alike.

column1: The Noldor who fled to [[Middle-earth]] following the [[Darkening of Valinor]] spoke Quenya among themselves. However
column3: who was the king of the [[Sindar]] (Elves of the Telerin line who remained in [[Beleriand]] instead of journeying to Valinor) learnt about their slaying of the Teleri
column4: he forbade the use of Quenya in all his realm. The Sindar had been slow to learn Quenya anyway
column5: while the Noldor at this time had fully mastered Sindarin.

column1: The Quenya used in Middle-earth of the [[Third Age]] (the time of the setting of ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'') had come to be a scholarly pursuit; it was not typically used in conversation. It was preserved as a formal language and for writing; Sindarin was the vernacular of all Elves. However
column2: the Noldor still remembered Quenya and valued it highly; for example
column3: [[Gildor]] and his party appreciated [[Frodo Baggins]]'s greeting ''Elen síla lúmenn' omentielvo''. ("A star shines on the hour of our meeting.") [[Galadriel]] was perhaps the only  Elf in Middle-earth during the events of ''The Lord of the Rings'' who had learned Quenya as a cradle-tongue:  she was born in Valinor
column4: during the days of the Two Trees. Noldorin (Exilic) Quenya differed somewhat from Valinórean Quenya
column5: because the language continued to evolve after exile
column6: and it underwent some regularisation as it became a language of lore. There were also a few changes in pronunciation.

column1: The poem [[Namárië]] is the longest piece of Quenya found in the ''Lord of the Rings''. It is also known as Galadriel's Lament.

column2: but worked out in a self-consistent character not precisely like any language that I know.|[[J.R.R. Tolkien]]|[[Parma Eldalamberon 17]]

column1: Quenya's phonology and grammar are most strongly influenced by Finnish
column2: which is an agglutinative language; grammatical inspiration also comes from Latin and Greek. The phonology is also based on Finnish
column3: and to a lesser extent Latin
column4: Italian and Spanish.  Some interesting phonological rules are that no consonant cluster can begin or end a syllable (with one exception
column6: a word may not end in a non-dental consonant
column7: and voiced stops must be preceded by sonorants. The first two of these phonotactic rules also exist in Finnish.

column1: The most striking feature of Quenya is that it is a highly agglutinating language
column2: meaning that multiple affixes are often added to words to express grammatical function. It is possible for one Quenya word to have the same meaning as an entire English sentence. For example
column3: one could say "I have found it" in Quenya in a single verb

column1: Tolkien intended Quenya to be an archaic
column2: ancient and august language for the peoples of Middle-earth of the Third Age
column3: being the cultural analogue of Latin in Europe<ref>{{app|F1i}}</ref><ref>{{L|347}}</ref>. For that reason
column4: he decided to make Quenya look like Latin ocularly<ref>{{L|144}}</ref> and substituted K for C and Q for QU.

column1: Tolkien wrote much more material about Quenya and his other languages than he published in his lifetime.  In fact
column4: originally invented Middle-earth and its inhabitants as a means of imposing upon his artificial languages a history of war
column5: migration and suffering. The famous novels might be considered incidental to his further and more passionately developed linguistic hobby.  The journals ''Vinyar Tengwar'' and ''Parma Eldalamberon'' are devoted to editing and publishing Tolkien's linguistic papers.

column1: Quenya is one of many constructed languages introduced over the years by science fiction and fantasy writers
In early [[J.R.R. Tolkien|Tolkien]]'s writings (see: ''[[The History of Middle-earth]]'')
column2: this language was called '''[[Qenya]]''' (although pronounced the same as ''Quenya'')
column3: and it underwent countless revisions in both grammar and vocabulary before it reached the form found in ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'' and ''[[The Silmarillion]]''. The term Qenya is now used to distinguish between old Qenya and the new Quenya. However
column4: the fluid nature of Quenya (or Qenya
column5: for that matter) makes such a distinction a highly disputed one.
